claims_summary: CIA-seeded data analytics company providing surveillance and targeting platforms to intelligence community, military, and law enforcement with classified capabilities and controversial domestic use

cia_founding: In-Q-Tel $2 million seed investment (2004) - documented in In-Q-Tel disclosures
Peter Thiel public statements about CIA relationship
Early CIA contracts documented in federal procurement databases
Alex Karp interviews describing intelligence community origins
government_contracts: CIA contracts: Federal procurement data, Palantir SEC filings
NSA contracts: Budget documents, public reporting
ICE contracts: $51M+ documented via FOIA and procurement records
DoD contracts: Hundreds of millions annually (SEC filings)
surveillance_capabilities: Palantir Gotham: Intelligence analysis platform documentation
Data integration: Combines FBI, CIA, NSA, military databases
Targeting support: Investigative journalism on kill list operations
Predictive policing: Law enforcement contracts documentation
ICE deportation operations: Internal documents revealed via leaks
controversies: Employee protests over ICE contracts (2018) - media coverage
Targeting civilians: Investigative reports on Afghanistan/Iraq operations
Domestic surveillance concerns: Law enforcement contracts
Lack of transparency: Classified capabilities shield from scrutiny
concealment_mechanisms: Classified contracts: Capabilities not publicly disclosed
SEC filings provide limited operational details

validation_status: Well-documented through In-Q-Tel disclosures, federal procurement databases, SEC filings, investigative journalism, and internal documents - classified capabilities remain opaque
